Basic usage

A simple tap always does what is displayed on the key, a long tap shows all the functions of that key as suggestions, along with the gestures that trigger them.
The suggestion bar also contains a key that displays the whole layout with all mapped characters, and below it you will can also find this text ☺.

About gestures

In addition to a single tap, you may also drag a key to one of the 8 main directions: N, NW, W, SW, S, SE, E, NE (single swipe), or you can drag it away and back to the key (forth-and-back or double swipe).
These drag gestures will produce a modified form of the letters, eg. with accent, softened form, with consonant mark, some kind of variant.
For example, on Latin layout a NE swipe on a letter will add an acute accent to it (a→á), on Cyrillic layout a S swipe will produce the softened form of that letter (а→я), etc.

About the keys

Letter keys

They produce letters of the chosen alphabet by tapping, and their modified/related forms by the gestures. Where these gestures encode accents, they somewhat resemble the motion how you would write the accent mark, although it was not always possible.
For details see the gestures of different alphabets below.

Number keys

Even simpler, they produce the numbers, with the alphabet choosing as special functions via gestures. (In Arabic layout the Arabic number forms are also available via gestures.)

Control keys

Their special functions contain the non-alphabetical items like clipboard handling.

  • Shift: caps mode, ctrl, esc, hide keyboard
  • Space: tab and underscore
  • Enter: select all
  • Backspace, Up and Down arrows: cut, copy and paste text
  • Left and right arrows: start and end of selection

Multifunctional keys

All the other non-alphabetical characters are mapped to four multifunctional keys, vaguely grouped by similarity in function, but their gestures were assigned only by the frequencies of the symbols.

  • At-sign: braces (square, round, curly, angled)
  • Dollar: mathematical operators
  • Dot: punctuation
  • Quote: quote marks, ampersand, hash, tilde

Latin gestures

  • NE: acute
  • SW: bar
  • N-S: caret
  • E-W: cedilla
  • SW-NE: double acute
  • S: dot
  • NW: grave
  • S-N: hacek
  • E: macron
  • W-E: ogonek
  • N: ring
  • NE-SW: tilde
  • W: umlaut/diaeresis
  • SE: special/related symbol

Cyrillic gestures

  • S: soft form
  • W: alternate variant
  • SW: soft form of alternate
  • SE: with descender
  • NE: with upturn

Greek gestures

  • NE: with tonos
  • W: with dialytika
  • SE: special/related symbol

Arabic gestures

For alif, waw, ya

  • S: with maddah
  • S-N: with hamza
  • SW: hamza below
  • SE: alef maksura

For consonants

  • N: with shaddah
  • S: related letter
  • S-N: related with shaddah

Georgian gestures

  • S: related letter
  • W: ejective form
  • SW: ejective form of related letter
